pullRequest.body:
These linters are meant to run on all of mathlib, but they need to be imported in order to run on a given file.
Hence, move them to `Mathlib.Init`, which has precisely this purpose.

All linters moved in this PR are syntax linters (which need to be imported to run) which are enabled by default.
Linters missing from this list include
- Linter/Textbased (which is not syntax-based)
- Linter/MinImports (which is off by default)
- Linter/HaveLet (which is disabled right now)

All linters only have imports in `Lean`, except for `Linter/Lint` (which imports `Batteries.Tactic.Lint` to define an environment linter). This import could be avoided by splitting the environment linters into a different file; there is no need to import these syntax linters this early.

---

`semorrison` [indicated](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Duplication.20in.20style.20linters/near/463325858) that these linters are fine to import for now.

Follow-up clean-ups, out of scope of this PR
- write a linter to ensure Mathlib.Init is actually imported in every file
- remove the text-based line length linter (which is now duplicate)
- adapt the in-flight PR for the file length linter

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #15868 (mathlib adaptations, first part)
- [x] depends on: #15869 (adapting mathlib, the rest)

-->

I pushed a commit fixing almost all tests. `tests/MinImports.lean` needs more careful thought. @adomani Do you have a moment to take a look?
!bench
I'm not at a computer, but is the error just some whitespace noise?  I'm only going by what I can see in the CI report, though.

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/0148ae4d-6a57-48a5-87fd-c66fbcfe5121) for commit 3f6f5389fe50eee489edbcaf8a2a1279e3b405d4.
There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/ec9a28bb-60d4-44ab-8057-71f264eeb94e/to/0148ae4d-6a57-48a5-87fd-c66fbcfe5121) against commit 5b6785cc6960c32620eafe6bca60d2271169d4e0.

Michael, thank you very much for using the file already!

I took the liberty of fixing the failing `MinImports` test and, while I was at it, I also reduced the imports in the remaining linters.

I think that all transitive imports are acceptable now, but let's see what the others think about it!

By the way, I am not completely sure about what changed with `MinImports`, but it is something that I had observed before.  I think that there are two paths to make the syntax typecheck and Lean genuinely uses one or the other depending on what is available.  I do not know why Lean now prefers the "shorter" path, but I would not worry about it too much.

Oops, I merged master by mistake, sorry!

By the way, I think that back-porting all the linting changes would be welcome!
Thanks for quickly fixing the test, and tweaking the linters. I just filed #15868 and (edit: changed) #15872 for backporting the linter fixes.

I have added a comment inlining Mathlib.Tactic.Linter: it only contained a single import now, and was only meaningfully imported in Mathlib.Tactic.Common. (And, to be honest, I'm not convinced importing it in `Tactic.Basic` is not a better choice... but that's for another thread.)
The first PR has landed; I have just rebased on master.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#15868~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#15869~~

There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/6f356a21-4c4f-4b43-b020-5ba64485b050/to/9a36185a-434f-4280-8531-1fa81154db88) against commit e8679e49ac8a467f2439ff3f145dc9266a3154da.

Thanks!

maintainer merge

If I remember correctly, the only reason for this linter to use `HashSet`s is for its exception list, that I expected to be long.  I think that it currently contains a single exception (`#adaptation_note`), so the imports can easily be reduced, using an `Array` or even inlining the check.

Probably inlining is *not* better in this case, since I suspect that at various times it will be useful to modify the exceptions.
Agreed about inlining - thanks for the context!
I went for `Array` and reduced the imports.

Similarly here: the string matcher is there since one of the linters currently uses `findSubstring` or something like this.  I think that a previous version of the linter used `splitOn` and counted the pieces: that would allow to reduce the imports.
Medium-term, I wonder whether `findSubstring` ought to get upstreamed into `Std` - but that might take longer than we'd like.
Sure, if we can avoid increasing imports, I am happy with a different solution.  The one using `splitOn` is very low tech and yet robust, though.

The "unreachable" dependence is just for some name resolution double ticks to work: making those silently not exist using a single tick would allow removing the dependence.  In this case, I am not completely sure how the behaviour of the linter would change.
Looking at the code, those names only play a role when they are available and do not cause any concern otherwise, so I removed the import and used single ticks.

I expressed my preference for a docstring in the creation of `Mathlib.Init` because I thought it's useful not to have an empty [doc page](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Init.html), and my personal preference remains unchanged.
That is a fair point. There is an annoying detail that imports must come before module docstrings, but I can be convinced that the doc generation page is a better argument.

What speaks against just doing this:

```lean
import Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.HashCommandLinter
import Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.GlobalAttributeIn
-- This file imports Batteries.Tactic.Lint, where the `env_linter` attribute is defined.
import Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.Lint
import Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.OldObtain
import Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.RefineLinter
import Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.UnusedTactic
import Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.Style

/-!
This is the root file in Mathlib: it is imported by virtually *all* Mathlib files.
For this reason, the imports of this files are carefully curated.
Any modification involving a change in the imports of this file should be discussed beforehand.
Here are some general guidelines:
* no bucket imports (e.g. `Batteries`/`Lean`/etc);
* every import needs to have a comment explaining why the import is there;
* strong preference for avoiding files that themselves have imports beyond `Lean`, and
  any exception to this rule should by accompanied by a comment explaining the transitive imports.

## Linters

All syntax linters defined in Mathlib which are active by default are imported here.
Syntax linters need to be imported to take effect, hence we would like them to be imported
as early as possible.

All linters imported here have no bulk imports;
**Not** imported in this file are
- the text-based linters in `Linters/TextBased.lean`, as they can be imported later
- the `minImports` linter, as that is still disabled by default.
It *does* check a useful global coherence property, so perhaps changing this default at some
point can be useful. `mathlib` might need a fair amount of fixes for this to become viable, though.
-- XXX: the `haveLet` linter could also be imported here...
-/

```
This is a good solution; I've switched to it. Thanks!

This sentence/parenthesis does not make sense to me. I read it as "[...] are syntax linters which are active by default and which do not need to be import as early as possible" -- why are we doing it then?
Oops, that is a negation too much. I have reworded this comment.

I don't know what the mathlib standard is for this. My gut tells me that `Mathlib/Tactic/Linter.lean` should keep existing, maybe be autogenerated, still import all linters, and keep being imported in `Mathlib.Tactic.Common` (or `Mathlib.Tactic.Basic`).

Hm. From a code writing perspective, an essentially empty file feels silly. This can be nice from a documentation perspective, though...

Ultimately, I would like to have a place to put a big comment documenting the linters, what they do and their current state (like [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/c64a270a650434893fc6da7c434448ff01a344b0/Mathlib/Init.lean)). If you think `Tactic.Linter.lean` is a good place, I can get behind that.
I don't feel strongly about this.

it's not that uncommon to have a file to support `import Mathlib.Tactic.Linter`, that's analogue to `import Mathlib.Tactic`, and indeed, the module docstring of that file would probably be a good place for a manual documentation.

Anyways, I think if you want to remove `Mathlib/Tactic/Linter.lean` I think you should ask some maintainers or Zulip about their opinion, I don't think I should be the one calling a decision here :)
Fair point; I have restored that file now.
(see comment about `Mathlib.Tactic.Linter`)

```suggestion
set_option linter.style.setOption false

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: import enabled mathlib syntax linters in `Mathlib.Init`
